ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned asl and Deaf culture
Continuing to explore the language of ASL. Furthering our engagement and knowledge of deaf culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The professors are incredible, especially professor Fisher. He is so accommodating and engaging and hilarious. Take asl with him

A strength of this course is how students are immersed in learning ASL through ASL culture. This feature of the course made it extremely interactive, making it easier to learn the language. One weakness of the course, in my opinion, is the requirement for attending a certain amount of events and logging the hours. While I understand the motive, I think the requirement falls a bit flat in terms of accessibility. There is a certain privilege in assuming that all ASL students have expendable time outside of class. Many Yale students come from low-income backgrounds, may pay for their education themselves, and need the time outside of class to work students jobs. Outside the realm of "time is money", students, whether working or not, do also value the rest time they are allotted outside of class. Yale is an extremely taxing environment to be in for 9 months. Rest is necessary. Requiring a certain amount of hours for event engagement may create resentment towards the ASL program instead of community.
Well structured lectures and many out of class opportunities to further your learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I think the entire ASL department is extremely welcoming and prioritizes its students and their learning.
I would recommend this class to someone who is looking for a different type of language, one that uses the physical instead of audio.
